bibl.title: Letter from John E. Worden, Jr., to Philip Showalter Hench, September 28, 1951

div1.p: Worden informs Hench about the Washington, D.C., Virginia, and New York University College of Medicine activities commemorating the centennial of Reed's birth. The Washington Post carried an article featuring Cornwell's painting and a photograph of Blossom Reed.

div1.head: Letter from John E. Worden, Jr., to Philip Showalter Hench, September 28, 1951
div1.opener:
ARMY MEDICAL CENTER
WASHINGTON 12, D. C.
September 28, 1951
MEDEC -B
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Thank you for your letter concerning Major Walter Reed's 100th anni-
versary. Unfortunately I have been on leave and unable to reply
sooner.

Here in Washington, September 13 was proclaimed “Walter Reed Day” by
the Commissioners governing the District of Columbia. The ceremony
for presentation of the proclamation was attended by Major General
Walter Reed, Colonel Joseph F. Siler and General Streit.

The Army Medical Museum conducted a special exhibit, while the Army
Medical Center was renamed Walter Reed Army Medical Center.

This was all that took place in Washington, since the big plans which
we had hoped for involving the highest Government officials had to
be cancelled when these officials were unable to come. During that
time we were constantly on the alert to get in touch with you should
the event materialize.

The State of Virginia's Governor called for a state-wide observance
of the centennial. At Gloucester and Belroi a program of commemora-
tion was sponsored by the Virginia Medical Society and the Gloucester
County Junior Chamber of Commerce. General Streit, scheduled to be
principal speaker at this event had to cancel out because of airplane
engine trouble. Brig. General Standlee read his speech.

At Harrisonburg, Colonel Joseph U. Weaver, deputy post commander of
the Center, was the principal speaker and led a parade from Stoneleigh
to Walter Reed Hall on Madison College campus where ceremonies were
held.

New York University's College of Medicine opened a special Walter Reed
exhibit at a tea held the 13th, at which a new portrait of Major Reed
was unveiled. Special messages from Major General George Armstrong
and General Streit were read.

The Commissioners of the county encompassing Murfreesboro, North Carolina
also declared September 13 as Walter Reed Day.

The Washington Post carried a full page color reproduction of the Cornwell
painting as well as an article on Major Reed and an Associated Press pic-
ture of Mrs. Blossom Reed. I had presumed that the Post had contacted
you since they were eager for your address.

A local Washington television station WTTG (Dumont) devoted a major por-
tion of their Sunday, September 16 “Pentagon-Washington” program to the
anniversary. In addition to General Streit, there appeared a Miss Lena
Townshend, former Army contract nurse from Baltimore, Maryland who claims
to have fed sugar water to the mosquitoes Major Reed used in his experi-
ments in Cuba.

Another local television station WTOP (Columbia Broadcasting Company)
also paid tribute on an evening program September 14.
With many thanks for your assistance in this centenary period, I remain,

closer.signed:
JOHN E. WORDEN, JR.
Public Information Officer
